Mr. Seymour Siegel
Radio Station WNYC
New York City, New York
Dear Sis
This is a subject about which I should have written you sooner but
which should be given consideration by the Board on the 18th.
Dr. J.R. Morton, Director of Continuation Education in the Exten¬
sion Division at the University of Alabama,who was the University
representative at the Biloxi convention (not by accident) is the
National University Extension Association chairman on atomic energy
and last year, through cooperation of the AEC, promoted with money
contributed by the AEC the traveling exhibit on atomic energy, a
project costing upwards of $100,000. This project, conceived and
supervised almost entirely by Dr« Morton, has pleased the AEC
immensely and they are now ready to listen to other ideas from him.
Dr. Morton win write you a letter within the next few days
soliciting the suggestions and support of the NAEB for a project
adult education on atomic energy utilizing radio. I think it will be
a very excellent opportunity for us to capitalize upon a contact and
perhaps get some additional money for the production of programs for
our network. He will probably ask that you set up a committee to work
with him and my purpose in writing in advance of his letter is to
tell you that I personally feel that it is an opportunity which we cannot
pass up. Incidentally, Dr. Morton formed a very high opinion of the
membership of NAEB at the Biloxi meeting and said on a number of occasions
that he thought it was a wide awake and intelligent group of people
going about important business in a business-like way.
A second point worthy of consideration is that Dr. Morton has just
accepted a position as consultant with the adult education division
of the Ford Foundation and will devote half of his time to this job.
It is at this point 100# secret. His assignment, I understand, will
be to make an inventory and evaluation of the adult education activi¬
ties of the extension division arms of the colleges and universities
of the country—including educational radio stations. This latter
assignment of his obviates my interest in our cooperating vigorously
with his atomic energy project. I think you might even wire him an
invitation to meet with the Board in New York if you get his letter
concerning the AEC business soon enough.
As I have indicated, this letter must be held in the strictest
confidence. In the first place, he does not know that I know of his
